snippet: Despite their friendship, Angela Merkel and Christine Lagarde face difficult discussions over how to handle a future crisis, with opposing stances on the amount of money needed to protect vulnerable economies and how it should be raised.
abstract: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and International Monetary Fund managing director Christine Lagarde have opposing stances on how much money is required to prop up vulnerable European economies, despite their unusually close relationship; Lagarde has argued that Europe needs at least $1 trillion in emergency funds from the IMF and member nations, figure contested by Merkel, whose German constituency is opposed to committing more money to rescue its neighbors.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS KULISH and ANNIE LOWREY
byline.contributor: Nicholas Kulish reported from Berlin, and Annie Lowrey from Washington. Liz Alderman contributed reporting from Paris.

lead_paragraph: Despite their friendship, Angela Merkel and Christine Lagarde face difficult discussions over how to handle a future crisis, with opposing stances on the amount of money needed to protect vulnerable economies and how it should be raised.

headline.seo: Merkel and I.M.F. Chief Are Friendly Opponents On Europe’s Debts
headline.main: German Leader and I.M.F. Chief Split Over Debt
